summary: RAG evaluation refers to the process and methodologies used to assess the performance of Retrieval-Augmented Generation systems, which combine retrieval of relevant documents with generative capabilities to produce accurate and context-aware responses. This evaluation encompasses specialized metrics and frameworks focusing on exactness, functional correctness, and similarity to reference data. It plays a critical role in the AI engineering lifecycle, particularly in pipeline development, model selection, fine-tuning, and deployment. Recent advances, such as the ViDoRe V3 benchmark, push RAG evaluation into complex, multimodal, real-world scenarios involving visual elements and multi-document synthesis, highlighting ongoing challenges and model limitations.
why_it_matters: Evaluating RAG systems with rigorous frameworks and metrics ensures high-quality, reliable AI applications by verifying that retrieved and generated outputs meet functional correctness and relevance criteria. It helps developers avoid costly trial-and-error in fine-tuning and deployment by providing early quality signals. High-quality evaluation benchmarks like ViDoRe V3 stimulate research and innovation, particularly in handling complex multimodal data and grounding outputs in verifiable sources. This maintains user trust, sets realistic performance expectations, and guides iterative improvements in LLM engineering and AI system design.

Note that we never said not to use OpenAI’s GPT API, just that the LLM framework we will pres-
ent is LLM-agnostic. Thus, if it can be manipulated programmatically and exposes a fine-tuning 
interface, it can be integrated into the LLM Twin system we will learn to build. The key to most 
successful ML products is to be data-centric and make your architecture model-agnostic. Thus, 
you can quickly experiment with multiple models on your specific data.

updates.title: ViDoRe V3: A Comprehensive Evaluation of Retrieval Augmented Generation in Complex Real-World Scenarios
updates.body: ViDoRe V3 benchmark addresses multimodal and multi-document challenges in RAG evaluation by providing high-quality annotations across 10 datasets and 6 languages. Evaluation results show advances and persistent limitations of state-of-the-art RAG pipelines on complex visual data and multi-type queries, fostering progress with a commercially permissive release.

patch_notes: Added ViDoRe V3 update introducing a large-scale multimodal RAG evaluation benchmark that incorporates visual and multi-document complexity, expanding the scope of RAG evaluation challenges and highlighting current model strengths and weaknesses.
